subject: junit-quickcheck: seeking feedback

Hi JUnit,

I've been working on junit-quickcheck (https://github.com/pholse=
r/junit-quickcheck) on and off for a while now, and wanted to solicit some =
feedback from potential users.

junit-quickcheck uses the ParameterSupplier=
 extension point of JUnit's Theories runner to feed a number of randomly ge=
nerated values to a @Theory method, as opposed to prescribing @DataPoint(s)=
. As its name suggests, it draws inspiration from the Haskell QuickCheck li=
brary (http://www.cse.chalmers.se/~rjmh/QuickCheck/).

Though the project i=
s built with Maven, none of the artifacts it produces are deployed to a cen=
tral Maven repo (yet). Some of its dependencies are still snapshot versions=
: they can be found here:

    -- https://github.com/pholser/junit.contrib
=

    The 'theories' module of junit.contrib contains a version of the Theor=
ies runner that should be current with the JUnit 4.11 implementation, but:
=
    1) better handles theory parameters involving generics
    2) uses the =
Paranamer (http://paranamer.codehaus.org/) library to allow ParameterSignat=
ures to carry a parameter's name
    3) is packaged as org.junit.contrib.th=
eories.*... rather than org.junit.experimental.theories.*...

    This is t=
he Theories runner that junit-quickcheck tests use. It in turn depends on:
=

    -- https://github.com/pholser/paranamer

If you choose to build junit-=
quickcheck, you'll need to build these dependencies too.

I'm interested in=
 any and all feedback, but am particularly interested in these items:

-- W=
ould size control be useful (e.g. maxSize on @ForAll)? Maybe size() gets co=
mputed on every generation, as with Haskell QuickCheck?
-- Do we need diffe=
rent random distributions/@Frequency?
-- What other basic generator configs=
 would be useful?
-- What other out-of-the-box generators would be useful?
=
-- Is the behavior of the out-of-the-box generators sufficient? What should=
 be changed, if anything?
-- nextLong(min, max) and nextDouble(min, max) --=
 getting them to span the entire range.
-- Is @SuchThat with OGNL and Paran=
amer useful, or cute but not that helpful? What about without Paranamer?

F=
eel free to check this project out, and drop me an email or post issues to =
the project's GitHub site. Thanks for your time!

Regards,
Paul Holser
